author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

I would recommend your version to start at `v1.0.0` if it is feature complete and the API seems to be stable. Current versions such as `v666.0.0` should only be used if there is a compelling reason (previous versions have been published and used by others, matches library or product being wrapped, etc).

I think he's trying to make a point about the package registration process lol:

+ https://discourse.julialang.org/t/reduce-package-registration-waiting-period/40954/22

Apparently you weren't supposed to catch this, so he could point out how easy it was to dupe

// the projects also worthless. so i guess you didnt catch that :P

> I think he's trying to make a point about the package registration process

Yes.

> Apparently you weren't supposed to catch this, so he could point out how easy it was to dupe

Absolutely not the point I'm trying to make (cf https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/16058)

> // the projects also worthless. so i guess you didnt catch that :P

You're getting closer. Who gets to decide the worth of a project?

> I think he's trying to make a point about the package registration process lol:
> 
> * https://discourse.julialang.org/t/reduce-package-registration-waiting-period/40954/22
> 
> Apparently you weren't supposed to catch this, so he could point out how easy it was to dupe
> 
> // the projects also worthless. so i guess you didnt catch that :P

@sbromberger reached out to me about the pull request. I wasn't just looking at new package registrations. My feedback is consistent with my comments on the thread. I see no issue with having a package that does one thing `istwo`. Per the current policy, we do have a policy on starting versions and no-skipping of versions unless there is a compelling reason which is what my comments addressed. I am against editorializing the registration process. Giving feedback from the community, yes. He is more than welcome to update the PR to start the version at `v1.0.0` if he wants. Per the current guidelines it would be merged after the waiting period and I have no objections.

> Per the current guidelines it would be merged after the waiting period and I have no objections.

The ultimate irony is that your first comment blocked the auto-merge :)
I don't think my comment did. The [noblock] applies to the author and maintainers. Would be weird if randos could block the automerge.
My understanding is that any comment blocks the automerge.

That might be a bug if thatâ€™s the case. The GitHub API gives with each comment block the user and one can get the permissions for the issue repo / whether one is an author from the first block text.
This is clearly in bad faith.

Just to close this out for anyone interested: the position espoused by some in this thread was that the registry should be open and that package quality or reasonableness should not be a factor in whether a package gets included in the registry [1] (counterargument here [2]). This came on the heels of a registration PR for a package that was obviously incorrect and was a simple single-function port of an obviously incorrect NPM package. The positions referenced above were made during the course of the debate over this package.

For the record, I am against the "NPM-ification" of the Julia Registry; I believe that packages should be curated with documented criteria that are as objective as possible and as unambiguous as possible when objectivity is difficult; and at the request of some of the project leaders, have started a discussion about it [3].

This PR was an attempt to figure out whether there was a set of undocumented subjective criteria that proponents of an open registry would use to deny an obviously-incorrect, simple, single-function package. From a correctness perspective, it is no more incorrect than the original package proposed.

As it turns out, there does appear some line that even the most staunch supporters of an open registry refuse to cross. It is apparently the assessment of the author's "faith". I am glad for this. My only request is that we document it.

[1] https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/1856#issue-635438890
[2] https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/15926#issuecomment-640578600
[3] https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/16058
@Nosferican Anyone can block AutoMerge. This is intentional to allow engagement from the community.
I don't care either way whether this package is merged or not, but I think it's a waste of everyone's time and energy, so I closed it. I get the point, but I do not appreciate how it was made.
